question: Letty, dear, is that a cat hair on your blouse?
answer: So, I got the district to approve my after-school math program.

question: How wonderful, darling. What does that mean for you?
answer: I'll be running it three days a week, and...

question: Will you get time off to do that?
answer: Not now, but maybe later, if they like the program. What's up with you?

question: No, Mom, it's more of a prestige thing.
answer: Mmmmmmm.

question: Ruth. Calling Ruth.
answer: Sorry.

question: Just go ahead and tell us.
answer: There's nothing to tell.

question: So, another one bites the dust.
answer: It's not another one. It's my sister. Aren't you happy for her?

question: She's only known the guy a few months. Can I put these here for tonight?
answer: In there's better. It's kind of romantic, don't you think?

question: I really think if you're going to spend your life with someone you want to know them pretty damn well.
answer: Believe me, I know your feelings on the matter.

question: The receptionist said you called earlier about something.
answer: My math program. The Superintendent said he'd fund it.

question: Good going. I knew you could do it. It looks like we're both bucking for advancement.
answer: Yeah?

question: Huntley told me today that if I come through on the Benton deposition, they may consider me for senior associate.
answer: Congratulations. We should celebrate.

question: I was thinking dinner on Friday with James and Meg at the Saint Mark.
answer: I mean tonight. Like right now...

question: Actually, I need to review the deposition questions tonight. Maybe tomorrow?
answer: Oh, ok. Maybe.

question: But I thought if you don't mind, you could listen and see how I come across?
answer: Sure. Of course.

question: Letty, please, I need your full attention.
answer: Let me have it. I'm sorry about your turtle Bobby, but you know we only have show-and- tell on Mondays. Today, we're scheduled for grammar. Don't even think about it. Class, why don't you... You guys pull out your verb sheets and review them.

question: Let me have it. I'm sorry about your turtle Bobby, but you know we only have show-and- tell on Mondays. Today, we're scheduled for grammar. Don't even think about it. Class, why don't you... You guys pull out your verb sheets and review them.
answer: She says she won't even come if Dad brings Monica.

question: Mom won't miss your wedding. She'll come around. I promise she will.
answer: How?

question: I'll talk to her, and to Dad, too. A few wisely-chosen guilt tactics and they'll be ours.
answer: Maybe if we had them both to dinner or something.

question: Maybe.
answer: You always throw the best dinner parties, Letty.

question: Oh, wait a minute, now I see where you're going.
answer: Please, Letty.

question: Mom and Dad? At dinner together? Are you crazy? Maybe, though. Maybe it would work. I could throw you an engagement party maybe.
answer: Really?

question: You know what, Ruthie? I better get back to my class, OK?
answer: And the party?

question: Yeah, it'll be fun.
answer: Thank you so much.

question: Who can come up here and give me a sentence with a "to be" verb in it? Come on up, Zach. Neater, Zach. Zach, you know the line by the "a" has to come straight down or it looks like an "o." What's wrong, Zach? Try again, Zach. Like that. I don't believe it. You still can't do it. No, it's not OK. You'll never get to college on OK. It has to be good, Zach. Do you understand me? I'm very, very sorry, Zach. You know what, guys? Wednesday's not a grammar day. It's a collage day. It's a collage ON THE WALL day. And, Zach? Zach, I want you to be in charge of paste.
answer: What are you doing? You're going to be late.

question: I'm calling in sick.
answer: You don't have a fever.

question: I don't feel like going to work today.
answer: Won't it be hard for them to get a substitute this late?

question: It'll be OK.
answer: But what about that math project?

question: Paul, I just can't go. Is that OK with you or am I committing some horrible crime?
answer: Forget I asked.

question: I'm sorry. I'm just...I'm so tired lately.
answer: Maybe you ought to see a doctor.

question: No, it's not like that. It's just I've got those parent conferences, and I'm supposed to set up the math program by next week.
answer: You can get out of the dinner.

question: No, I can't. I've already convinced both Mom and Dad to come.
answer: Come on, Letty. It'll get done.

question: I don't think so.
answer: Of course it will. Remember the big talent show you planned last year? And what about the Christmas benefit when Santa canceled at the last minute? But you still pulled it off.

question: Yeah.
answer: You just need to get more organized. L

question: Maybe.
answer: Let's make a list of the things you need to do, OK?

question: I see. Well... Oh. What the fuck. It's my job. Hit me. No more bear claws left?
answer: Oh, no thanks, I'm too excited to eat. Where's Mommy?

question: Do you have to call her Mommy?
answer: Where's the old bag I sometimes call Mommy?

question: She said she'd be here at 10.
answer: What do you think of this one?

question: I'd have to see it on.
answer: Have you been crying? Your eyes are all puffy.

question: Things have been kind of stressful lately.
answer: But everything's OK?

question: Yeah, everything's under control.
answer: What about the engagement party?

question: Everything's ready for tomorrow night--except the artillery.
answer: Thanks so much for planning it, Letty. Jake's really looking forward to it.

question: You better start trying on before the vultures get all the good ones.
answer: What about this one?

question: You look beautiful.
answer: Really?

question: Truly. Hi, Mom.
answer: Look, Mom, I think I've found the dress.

question: Letty, I think this would be beautiful on you.
answer: Oh no.

question: Paul could pop the question at any time.
answer: Mom, please.

question: Can I get you a glass of champagne? Hi, Dad, Monica. I'm so glad you could come. Mom, this is Monica. Monica, my mother, Martha. Dad, Mother, you've met before, right?
answer: How've you been, Martha?

question: It's mushroom-time, folks.
answer: I like the touch of cilantro. It is cilantro, isn't it?

question: You can always call it, Dad. Ruth's narrowed the dress hunt down to two, Dad.
answer: Tell me about them.

question: Puglia olives. Would I forget? A round of martinis coming right up.
answer: How can I help?

question: Paul, can you hand me the olives? Ruth, I need you to, what was it?
answer: What about the souffle? Has that gone in?

question: Olives Aux Herbes De Provence. I got the wrong kind of olives.
answer: What's all the dreck?

question: Sage, rosemary... Les Herbes.
answer: It'll be fine.

question: No, no. They've got to be Puglia olives, packed in a light brine with a flavor that doesn't overpower the palate.
answer: What are you doing?

question: Can you loan me a 20?
answer: Sure. Why?

question: I'm going to the store.
answer: I think you're overreacting.

question: I'll be back before you can say souffle. I can't find martini olives. All you have are black. They're not there. I need the ones from Puglia. They're the ones that are packed in brine, but they don't overpower the, you know, the palate. Where are they? Where are they? Where are they?
answer: What's wrong, Miss?

question: Tell me where they are.
answer: I think you should go now.

question: I need my olives.
answer: It's time to leave. Call security. Where's security, please?

question: Fucking olives. Fucking, fucking olives. No, no, no. Go away.
answer: Call police. Now.

question: Miss Mayer? Miss Mayer? I know you've had a rough night, but I have a few questions for you, Miss Mayer, or Letitia. Do you mind if I call you Letitia?
answer: Letty.

question: First off, Letty, can you tell me where you are?
answer: I answered these questions last night.

question: I know this can be a real drag, but the attending physician on day shift is required to do his own prelim exam when a patient is admitted during the night.
answer: Hillview Psychiatric Hospital.

question: Great. Now, Letty, I'd like you to remember three items. I'm going to ask you to repeat them in just a few minutes. They are chair, cup and ball. Did you get that? OK, let's subtract 6 from a succession of numbers starting with And 85 minus 6?
answer: No, 79. Sorry, this makes me nervous.

question: It's OK. It's not a pass-fail kind of thing. Now the three things I asked you to remember.
answer: Chair, cup and ball.

question: Terrific. Let me shift gears here a minute... Do you ever hear voices that other people don't hear or see things they don't?
answer: No.

question: What about patterns? Do you find yourself checking and re-checking locks? Or washing your hands over and over again? How about arranging your possessions in a certain way? Yes? Go right ahead.
answer: Sometimes my food, and my clothes, and my underwear.

question: How do you sort it--by lace and cotton?
answer: By color.

question: What if it's got a pattern?
answer: Is this really important? Because I don't think it's a problem.

question: I see. How long has it been since you've done something you've enjoyed, Letty?
answer: A while, I guess.

question: Hello, Letitia. I'm Dr. Emlee, and I have some questions to ask you...
answer: I did this already.

question: It's hospital policy...
answer: To be interviewed every hour?

question: I'm the only doctor making rounds this morning.
answer: Well, I don't have hallucinations. Honest.

question: This doctor, was he tall, with dark hair?
answer: Yeah, and a dimple.

question: I'm afraid Lhe's not a doctor.
answer: Psychologist, therapist, whatever.

question: Patient.
answer: What?

question: Michael, the man who came to see you, is a patient.
answer: What kind of place is this?

question: I apologize for the inconvenience, but I must ask you some...
answer: I want to see my mother immediately.

question: We discourage family visits for the first 48 hours after an emotional trauma like the kind you've experienced.
answer: I don't think you understand. I won't wait.

question: Treatment schedules are posted on the bulletin board. Dinner at 6, lights out at 10 and no fraternizing between patients. That's the rec room. We show movies there on Wednesdays and Fridays...And this is the dining hall.
answer: I'm really not that hungry.

question: Just eat whatever you want. This will give you a chance to meet some people.
answer: You know, my mom's coming to get me tomorrow. I'll be leaving.

question: I'm sorry. I'm so sorry.
answer: Oh, Letty, what happened?

question: Mom, I was there, and I just, I was so...
answer: I've talked to Doctor Emlee, and he says...

question: I'm so glad to see you. You can't believe the people in here. They've got patients posing as doctors...
answer: Everyone says it's the best facility in the area for this sort of thing.

question: I just want to go home. Can we go home now?
answer: I think the best thing for you right now is to stay here and get well.

question: Maybe I should talk about this with Ruth, or Paul.
answer: We all agree with the doctor, Dear. He thinks it's safer for you to stay here for a while.

question: You all really think I need to be here?
answer: Yes.

question: But what about Beast? Who'll...?
answer: Ruth's already taken him home.

question: And my class. It'll be hard to find a good substitute. And what about my math program?
answer: Paul said he'd call the school. And your father thinks he's convinced the guard not to press charges as long as you get help.

question: Charges?
answer: For his injuries. I guess you...I guess he got hit in the head. I packed up some of your clothes, and I can bring whatever else you need.

question: Mom, no, please don't go. Please.
answer: I'll see you soon.

question: Tomorrow?
answer: As soon as Dr. Emlee says.

question: Hey there. They're showing "Groundhog Day" if you...
answer: You took bets on my diagnosis?

question: It's no big deal. We all compare. Don't take it personally.
answer: You have no right, no right to take the worst thing that's ever happened to me and make it into some kind of game.

question: Stop acting like you're someone special. You're just like the rest of us.
answer: I'm not the one who's masquerading as a doctor. I'm not the one who's, who's...

question: Excuse me?
answer: What are you looking to read?

question: Anything interesting.
answer: This is good.

question: But you're checking it out.
answer: I've already checked it out 17 times.

question: You keep the book. I'm looking for Emily Dickinson.
answer: Hey, if you take the magic book, I'll feel like maybe you accept my apology and don't hate me anymore.

question: I haven't heard an apology.
answer: I'm really sorry I hurt your feelings. I got a little carried away. Can you ever forgive me? Mrs. Hallstrom, I'm pretty sure you could use that. Now, don't you have a gin rummy, Mrs. Hallstrom? Go ahead, now, just lay those cards down. Hot damn. Gin rummy. I told you so. You're three games up on me.

question: It's prettier here than I thought it would be.
answer: Yeah, I guess it's all right.

question: Are you all right?
answer: That's a big question.

question: I hope it wasn't something I did.
answer: Something you did?

question: That put you in here.
answer: Of course not, no. Is that why you're here?

question: I think we need to talk about some things.
answer: Yes, I suppose so.

question: This has been really difficult, this whole thing.
answer: No.

question: Especially this last year.
answer: Especially now.

question: So, I've been thinking a lot...
answer: I have too, Paul.

question: I talked to Ruth a little bit, and I think it's about time...
answer: I know. We can't just keep going through the motions.

question: Exactly. It's time to make decisions.
answer: You don't have to say anything else. I've known for a while that this was coming.

question: I just wish we'd done it sooner. Will you marry me? I had to smuggle it in here. I guess you're not really supposed to have jewelry.
answer: Or be up past ten or fraternize with other patients.

question: I hope you like it. It's a Marquis cut, 1.5 carats. They had one with emeralds around it, but this was simpler, more classic in its lines.
answer: It's, it's really nice, Paul.

question: You can take it back and we can have one custom made if you want.
answer: No, you've done a perfect job.

question: So, what do you say, Let?
answer: Do you think, really, that it's OK to get engaged when I'm in here?

question: Sure. We'll save the formal announcement for when you're out. I already told your mother. I hope you don't mind.
answer: No, no.

question: So will you?
answer: Of course. Yes. I will. I do.

question: Of course. Yes. I will. I do.
answer: You missed out on some great broccoli florets at dinner.

question: I wasn't hungry.
answer: John even managed to lob a load of mashed potatoes into Mrs. Hallstrom's milk.

question: Finally. I was getting tired of watching him try every night.
answer: Was it bad news--the visit from Peter?

question: Paul.
answer: He looked pretty serious.

question: He asked me to marry him.
answer: Very romantic setting.

question: It was romantic. He's very romantic.
answer: So are you engaged, or what?

question: What have you done with the ring?
answer: It's magic.

question: This isn't funny. Paul would kill me.
answer: Guess which hand.

question: Enough with the abracadabra.
answer: Guess. The fair maiden guesses incorrectly. Should we give her one more try? The audience says one more try. What guess you now?

question: The right one. Come on, Michael.
answer: With this ring, I thee...

question: Really, this isn't funny.
answer: OK, OK, I'll give it back. For a price.

question: Good God.
answer: A small price.

question: I won't do your portion of kitchen cleanup.
answer: No.

question: And I'm not covering for you when you sneak out to call Dominos.
answer: I want a kiss.

question: Get serious.
answer: I'm serious.

question: Everything's a joke with you.
answer: Here.

question: The medicine's still bothering me. It feels like I have cotton wrapped around my brain.
answer: We'll see about adjusting the dosage if that doesn't clear in the next How are other things going?

question: I think I've told you all the news. Let's see--the engagement. Oh, and my sister's coming to visit me, and they say my cat misses me.
answer: The question, Letty, is how are you feeling?

question: I can't believe you finally gave me the shirt.
answer: Loaned you. And it's only 'til you get out of here.

question: That settles it. I'm never leaving.
answer: I can hardly wait 'til you're free. Planning the wedding without you has been a disaster.

question: You're slowing.
answer: Mom and I fought for 20 minutes over whether we should go with ecru invitations or brilliant white. What do you think?

question: Ecru.
answer: And then the gold scroll or the black Romanesque print?

question: Do we have to talk wedding details?
answer: Oh, no, of course not.

question: I mean, you can always send me fabric samples to look at or pictures of dresses. But, it's been so long since we've seen each other.
answer: Of course. You're right. Besides, we should be talking about your engagement.

question: Tell me more about Beast beating up that other cat.
answer: Bloody furry mess, like I said. Aren't you so excited about Paul? Letty? What's going on with you, Letty?

question: Ruthie, do you ever wonder if you'll meet someone else...someone besides Jake?
answer: What's his name, Letty?

question: I didn't say...
answer: Don't even try. What's his name?

question: We're supposed to be asleep.
answer: Exactly.

question: We'll get caught.
answer: No rounds for another three hours. Nervous? Scared? Worried you're not fit for a caper of epic proportions?

question: Don't be ridiculous.
answer: Rendezvous at the closet in 30.

question: Letty, you should be in bed.
answer: There's a spider in my room.

question: Yeah?
answer: It's got a green dot on its back. I can't go to sleep with it watching me.

question: It had this red spot on its back.
answer: Green spot.

question: Mottled really. Green and red.
answer: I don't know why you feel you have to lie, Letty.

question: Lie?
answer: If you feel lonely, or need to talk, all you have to do is say so.

question: I don't mean to go on and on like this.
answer: It's OK. It's good to let it out. Did you ever tell Paul how you felt?

question: He was graduating from law school, and he just assumed I was OK with dropping out. We never really talked about it. But I know he was disappointed in me. I mean I'm just not sure I want the same things now that I did even a month ago. Is that so wrong?
answer: You can only do what feels best to you now.

question: You've been so great. I just feel a lot clearer about things.
answer: I'm glad.

question: And if I need to talk again...
answer: Yes, of course. Whenever you want.

question: I think it's a problem that you never told me about Michael. I had to hear it from another patient.
answer: I couldn't really say anything because of that fraternizing rule.

question: Well, Letty, this does present a liability issue for the hospital.
answer: I'm a grown woman, Dr. Emlee. I can take care of myself. I know Michael's a schizophrenic, and Mrs. Hallstrom's manic- depressive, and John Lockyer has episodes of psychosis, and I heard a rumor that you suffer from delusions of grandeur.

question: Go ahead and put the guard back up, Letty. But you need to know what you're dealing with.
answer: I don't need a lecture. I care about Michael.

question: Then that's even more reason to listen. Look, schizophrenics tend to withdraw from reality. They experience emotional disturbances that result in personality changes.
answer: Look, I know he's almost through with treatment here. And, he's on medication.

question: Drugs can help suppress symptoms. But lots of patients stop taking them when they're on their own because the side effects are so harsh. And, Michael's condition is often worsened by periods of stress. He's been in and out of...
answer: I don't want to hear anymore.

question: I'd like you to promise you won't carry on a relationship with Michael. Otherwise, I'll consider moving one of you to another ward.
answer: First you tell me to do what I want to, then you tell me to stop.

question: A daisy for the lady.
answer: The lady knows this is a dandelion.

question: A rose is a rose.
answer: Thanks. Where've you been all day?

question: Back-to-back sessions with the shrink.
answer: Sounds important.

question: I'm not allowed to see you anymore.
answer: Really? Me too.

question: I had to sneak by the guards to get here. They say you're highly unstable, have a depressive personality, and may hold back my own recovery.
answer: Wow. I'm bad news.

question: What's my rap?
answer: Schizophrenic recidivism marked by hallucinations and paranoid delusions.

question: Fuck. That's all true. Really, though. My thoughts go haywire sometimes.
answer: What are the delusions like?

question: I think people are after me, crap like that. Shocking, huh?
answer: Sure. But I took out a whole grocery store.

question: I wish I could have seen that.
answer: I'm starting to think that everyone's crazy to some extent.

question: Why in the world did you let me start talking in metaphors? That's no way for us to break up.
answer: Break up? They wish.

question: You must have spent thousands of dollars.
answer: Don't worry, Doctor, I didn't forget you.

question: Mrs. Hallstrom, you can't possibly afford to pay for this. It must go back.
answer: Why, no, Doctor. It can't. Most of it's for my daughter, Lily. She's coming to family day tomorrow...all the way from Cleveland with my grandson. You can't be taking away their "Welcome to California" presents.

question: It's so good to see you, Sweetheart.
answer: You too, Mom.

question: You're looking good. A little thin, but good. Thanks so much for doing this. Ruthie and Jake are up to a million things. And I just can't decide.
answer: Which flowers did you order?

question: We haven't. I wanted to talk that over with you, too.
answer: Oh, OK, well, better to choose the table cloths first anyway. This would complement the blue in the bride's maids' dresses. Look.

question: Where's your ring, Sweetheart?
answer: We aren't allowed to wear jewelry in here, Mom.

question: Just think, pretty soon, we'll be doing all these wedding preparations for you. Of course, if that's what you still want. Ruthie told me some silly story about a crush on some boy here.
answer: I haven't had a crush since I was

question: When did you start smoking?
answer: I'll put it out if it bothers you.

question: The puckering, dear. It doesn't seem so now, but in time, it will cause wrinkles around the mouth. You know, your life isn't about being in a mental hospital.
answer: What?

question: I hear this Michael fellow is schizophrenic.
answer: Mom, please.

question: Don't forget that Paul's a promising young attorney who loves you very much...
answer: Mom, look, if I want to dump Paul, I'll dump him. If I want to screw Michael or live with him or marry him, then I'll do that.

question: I'm only looking out for you.
answer: And if I want to smoke, I'll fucking smoke.

question: You must have thought about it. Everyone does.
answer: I just want to see Beast. Where would you go?

question: The mission up in Santa Barbara.
answer: No way.

question: That's where I always go when I get out.
answer: Why?

question: My dad used to take me there when I was little. It's totally quiet. And you can see the ocean for miles.
answer: What else would you do?

question: I'd like to drink a bottle of red wine with you and then make love to you and spend the whole night together. And we'd get up in the morning and spend hours lounging around and reading the paper.
answer: And we'd eat Spaghetti-O's in bed from the can.

question: How can you even mention Spaghetti- O's after eating Grandma Rosa's dinner tonight?
answer: I have a terrible confession.

question: Tell the doctor.
answer: I don't like lamb.

question: Then it's over.
answer: Lie down.

question: It's a good thing my family loves you.
answer: Your family just met me.

question: You're right. I guess I was projecting. What I should have said is, "It's a good thing I love you."
answer: Do you?

question: I do.
answer: Michael, I...

question: It's OK. You don't have to say anything.
answer: But I do. I love you, too.

question: Your Honor, I feel I should be released. I'm sufficiently able to look after... What? What?
answer: John and Nurse Gates are waiting for you.

question: Oh, right. I'm ready. How do I look?
answer: Great. I came to tell you to break a leg, and to give you this for good luck.

question: Why have you petitioned to leave the institution?
answer: I haven't had an episode in more than a month, Sir.

question: How do you plan to support yourself?
answer: My family's helping me out, Your Honor.

question: Where will you live upon release?
answer: Live?

question: Where do you plan to reside, Mr. Lockyer?
answer: With my mother.

question: Is your mother here today?
answer: That's the bitch. That cock- sucking bitch. She put me here. She did. She's the Satan that did this all.

question: The records indicate no major episodes in the past four months. And it seems you have the support of the staff.
answer: Yes, Sir.

question: But I see you've been in and out of the hospital more than ten times.
answer: Eleven, Your Honor. But I'm on a new medication now.

question: Do you feel ready to re-enter the world?
answer: Yes, Sir. My family is prepared to support me until I find a job. They've already located an apartment for me that's very near them.

question: What's so urgent? You've got me worried.
answer: I need to tell you something, and I'm not sure how.

question: You can tell me anything. Do you want to postpone the wedding? Is it too much pressure?
answer: No...

question: That's a load off my mind.
answer: Paul, I want to break off the engagement. I don't mean to hurt you. I know this is a terrible thing. And I have really loved you.

question: Whoa. Whoa. Have really loved me? Letty, it's natural to be nervous. But we're going to work through our problems.
answer: I've met someone else.

question: Who?
answer: It doesn't matter who.

question: Have you been seeing another teacher?
answer: No.

question: It's a doctor, isn't it? That's unethical. I'll have him rung up on malpractice charges so fast his head will spin.
answer: He's a patient here.

question: Of all the crazy things. I understood when you dropped out of law school. And during this whole mess, I've tried to be supportive. But, really, Letty, what can you be thinking?
answer: I love him.

question: You're going to throw away our life together for some shared experience with a looney-tune that you misguidedly think is love?
answer: Here's the ring.

question: No way. You keep the ring. You'll come to your senses.
answer: I've made my decision, Paul.

question: Tell me all.
answer: I was brilliant, or at least boringly sane.

question: So there were no problems?
answer: Not a one.

question: And did you go to the mission?
answer: No, you goof, I came to see you.

question: Just checking.
answer: I saw Paul leaving. Did you do the dirty deed?

question: Yeah.
answer: So, it's over?

question: All over. Did you see your new apartment?
answer: One bedroom, second floor, no view.

question: Furnished?
answer: No, I need some serious household advice.

question: First off, you'll need to go to Target. And, let's see, what should you buy?
answer: I better make a list.

question: Are you kidding? With those glazed eyes? I'm willing to bet 10 there was some break with reality going on there. Psychosis. Without a doubt, psychosis. But what I really can't believe is that I'm starting to actually miss work.
answer: Have you been in contact with the principal about your job?

question: I thought about calling, but I want to wait until I know when I'll be out.
answer: Then, you should call.

question: What?
answer: I think it's about that time, Letty. The charges against you have been dropped, the drugs have evened out and you seem to be dealing with your life quite well.

question: Are you saying I'm through with therapy?
answer: Let's not be hasty. I'm saying we should plan a release date for early next week.

question: Must you walk so quickly?
answer: It's good exercise, Mom.

question: I've got 26 years on you. If we could just slow down, we could talk so much easier. I'm so thankful you'll be leaving next week. If you want me to pick you up, I will.
answer: I've already made arrangements.

question: Ruthie mentioned that Michael might be coming for you.
answer: Mom, we agreed. You can visit, but you're not allowed to mention Michael.

question: Not even if it's something positive?
answer: Nyet. That's the condition.

question: Have you spoken to Paul at all?
answer: One more and you're out.

question: Honestly, Letty.
answer: A deal's a deal.

question: Have you heard the figure on how much Queen Elizabeth's going to pay in taxes this year?
answer: I knew you had it in you.

question: I knew you had it in you.
answer: So, we'll meet every Tuesday and Friday. And if you have any kind of emergency, you can page me.

question: OK, good. That's good. Thanks an awful lot for everything, and for coming down here to see me off.
answer: It was just a little going-away gesture.

question: I have a going-away gesture for you, too.
answer: Oh?

question: You know I will. Thanks for everything.
answer: See you later, guys. Aren't you supposed to throw a bouquet or something?

question: Aren't you ever quiet?
answer: Where to?

question: I've heard the mission in Santa Barbara is the place to go.
answer: This is it -- 3B. Check it out.

question: Open up. I want to see.
answer: Close your eyes. OK. Open them.

question: Wow.
answer: You like it?

question: I love the pillows.
answer: Throw pillows, Letty. The sales lady said they're the latest thing.

question: Very trendy. Let's see the rest. It's TV heaven.
answer: I was tired of watching what everyone else wants to watch. Now we can watch two shows at once.

question: Let's try out the bed.
answer: You've got to see the kitchen first. Do you like it?

question: I love your apartment.
answer: Really?

question: You'll never get rid of me. What do you say we go out to dinner to celebrate?
answer: Out? Are you kidding? I've got all the fixings here.

question: How can you not like the Top 10 List?
answer: I like it. But Headlines are better.

question: You're so wrong.
answer: Hey.

question: It's sex time.
answer: I think it's my turn.

question: Did I get spaghetti sauce on my face?
answer: No.

question: Michael.
answer: Shhhh. Letty? Rise and shine.

question: Not yet.
answer: I'll be forced to tickle you.

question: Go away.
answer: How about this? It's 10:30.

question: I'm supposed to meet the principal in half an hour.
answer: I'll see you tonight.

question: Good luck.
answer: You, too. Kick ass today.

question: My apartment tonight. You can meet Beast.
answer: Sounds good. Oh, and Letty?

question: Yeah?
answer: You've got one hell of a great body.

question: I didn't have any choice but to include the parents' letters in your file.
answer: Well, I understand. I know my behavior was poor.

question: So, in light of how the parents feel, and the fact the students are doing so well with the substitute, I don't think I can put you back in the classroom just yet.
answer: Look, Gail, I've been a good teacher.

question: I know, Letty. But the incident with Zach was frightening for the children. Now if you'd come to me, explained what was going on...
answer: Believe me, I wish I'd understood what was going on. I've worked really hard to get better. I've already thought about how to tell the kids where I was. And I'd like to send the parents this letter of explanation. With your support, I think they can accept me.

question: It's a very nice letter. But I have to go with what's best for the students.
answer: What does that mean?

question: I need someone to work on budget projections.
answer: Office work?

question: That's Mr. Beast to you.
answer: How was your day?

question: I bombed. It's either work in the office or nothing.
answer: Sounds grim.

question: Yeah. How was the job search? Who ever said sanity was fun?
answer: It doesn't matter. It'll work out.

question: Promise?
answer: Promise. As long as we have steak.

question: Steak?
answer: It's a well-known fact that a red- meat dinner can cure the blues. You and Beast wait here. I'll be back in a jiff. While I'm gone why don't you slip into something a little more naked? Don't ever talk about me again, you hear me?

question: I thought maybe you got lost.
answer: The store was busy.

question: You got wine. That's great.
answer: Would you mind if we just called it an early night?

question: Are you OK?
answer: Big restaurant interview tomorrow.

question: But what about the red meat-blues thing?
answer: You know, we've got that dinner with my parents tomorrow, too. I should really get some rest tonight.

question: How's filet sound?
answer: No, no, no. Not now. No.

question: I'll never Mget the hang of this. Hi, Frank. Maybe we should make lamb next week. How'd it go? What happened?
answer: Four interviews. Four no-gos.

question: The restaurant, too?
answer: I couldn't even face that one.

question: That's OK. We can call and reschedule in the morning.
answer: You don't have to take care of me, you know. Just promise you'll love me even if I end up in a job where I have to wear a blue polyester cap.

question: I think you know I'd love you even more in a blue polyester cap. You're going to miss the Top Ten.
answer: Coming.

question: Michael, hurry. I think I could get the program up and running in the next two weeks.
answer: From what I understand the principal has removed you from student activities.

question: She's worried that I'm unstable. But I wouldn't push for the program if I wasn't ready.
answer: What about the office work?

question: I'd have to do that, too. But I've gotten better at pacing myself.
answer: Are you sure?

question: I'll call you if I have problems. Scout's honor.
answer: I have to say I'm inclined to give it another try. But, Letty, why don't you give yourself three weeks to set it up this time?

question: Congratulations.
answer: Michael, the shop's about to close. Maybe you could try on your tux.

question: Michael just got a job. Couldn't you congratulate him?
answer: I will, Dear. I promise. Why McDonald's?

question: He's been looking everywhere for weeks, Mom. It's not that easy after you've been locked away.
answer: I've read that lots of people my age are supplementing their incomes these days by working at McDonald's and Burger King.

question: I'm going to take that as an honest effort at being open minded.
answer: Don't be fresh.

question: Just remember that I love him.
answer: I'll say this, Dear. He looks damn good in a tuxedo.

question: Aunt Lily is the one who married your father's cousin?
answer: No, that's Aunt Connie. Lily is the one who looks like a hooker.

question: Oh. And, Harry, he's the one who likes magic?
answer: You don't have to know all this by Saturday. It took me years.

question: Aunt Lily?
answer: Bingo.

question: The worst was when I stammered Jake's name.
answer: I don't think people even noticed. I thought the ceremony was perfect.

question: That's thanks to all your help.
answer: Uh oh, Uncle Cort at 6 o'clock.

question: I don't think I've seen you in two or three years.
answer: Has it been that long?

question: You were with that lawyer.
answer: I'm dating Michael now.

question: Met him in the receiving line. What is it that he does for a living?
answer: Well, he just got a job...

question: Speak of the devil. How did you guys meet again?
answer: At the psych hospital.

question: I would've sent a card, but your aunt and I, we weren't sure if that was the thing to do.
answer: That's fine, Uncle Cort.

question: Bye, Uncle Cort. What's with the lie?
answer: It wasn't exactly a lie.

question: Pretty close.
answer: People at weddings don't want the truth.

question: It's not good to drink so much with the medication you're on.
answer: What's with this music? I'll go talk to the D.J. and see if we can't get something good going.

question: Thanks, dad. Michael? Michael? You should come to bed. Did you take the aspirin and water? You don't want to feel awful in the morning. I'll get you some. What is it? Are you OK?
answer: Always the drugs.

question: What?
answer: I saw you talking to my Mom.

question: We both talked to her, Michael. And your dad.
answer: Why'd you tell her I wasn't taking my meds?

question: What do you mean not taking your meds?
answer: Why'd you tell?

question: I didn't talk to her about medications, Michael. Don't be silly.
answer: Silly? Silly am I?

question: Michael, take it easy.
answer: Silly, silly, silly.

question: I think I should call someone.
answer: Don't upset my Mom. Don't you upset my Mom.

question: Michael, calm down. Please. It's Michael, stop.
answer: Not my Mom. Not my silly silly Mom.

question: I've got an emergency. I'm at... 1450 North Jenkins. Apartment 2. My boyfriend's out of control. Please, please, send someone. No, he's having an attack. He's schizophrenic... I'm sorry, so sorry. I never should have called.
answer: You did the right thing.

question: I ruined your wedding night.
answer: I'm glad you called. Now, not another word about it. Oh my God. Did he hurt you?

question: Oh, Ruthie, what am I going to do? But what am I going to do?
answer: Do you want to go see him? I'll take you if you want to go.

question: I can't. I can't see him there. I was so sure. I really thought it would work. We have plans, Ruth.
answer: I know. I know.

question: I'm glad you agreed to see me.
answer: I'm just glad there aren't any hard feelings.

question: Oh, none. None. I completely understand what was going on.
answer: Oh.

question: How's work going? Are you back at school?
answer: I start on Monday.

question: So things are back on track?
answer: Getting back.

question: I heard about your friend.
answer: What?

question: I heard your friend was back in the hospital.
answer: Michael. Yes.

question: I just wondered, well, if this meant there was a chance for us. Because I think about you a lot, and I still feel...
answer: Our relationship meant a lot to me, too, Paul. But it's over. And Michael being in the hospital doesn't really change things.

question: I think I've heard this speech before.
answer: I'm really sorry. Sure, I understand. Wait. Wait. I need to give you this.
